content.text: Candida endophthalmitis is the most common form of endogenous (hematogenous) endophthalmitis. It occurs when Candida species, typically Candida albicans, spread to the eye through the bloodstream from a distant site of infection. Major risk factors include candidemia, central venous catheters, recent abdominal surgery, total parenteral nutrition (TPN), broad-spectrum antibiotic use, and intravenous drug use. The infection seeds the highly vascular choroid and retina.

pairs.value: Early on, may be asymptomatic. As it progresses, patients report floaters, blurred vision, and eye pain. Systemic symptoms of candidemia (fever, chills) may be present.

The classic finding is a chorioretinitis, which appears as a creamy-white, fluffy lesion in the retina or choroid. Lesions can extend into the vitreous, forming "fluff balls" or a "string of pearls" appearance. Vitritis (inflammation of the vitreous) is common. Anterior chamber inflammation and hypopyon can also occur.

content.text: Diagnosis is often clinical, based on the characteristic funduscopic findings in a patient with risk factors or confirmed candidemia. A dilated fundus examination by an ophthalmologist is mandatory for all patients with candidemia, even if asymptomatic.

content.name: Blood Cultures
content.interpretation: Positive blood cultures for Candida confirm the systemic infection.
content.notes: Blood cultures can be negative in up to 50% of cases of proven Candida endophthalmitis.

content.name: Vitreous or Aqueous Humor Biopsy
content.interpretation: Culture or PCR of intraocular fluid provides a definitive diagnosis but is reserved for cases where the diagnosis is uncertain or there is no response to therapy.

content.text: Management requires both systemic and local (intravitreal) antifungal therapy and should be coordinated between an infectious disease specialist and an ophthalmologist.

components.dose: Loading dose, then 200-300 mg (4 mg/kg) twice daily

criteriaBasedDuration.description: Treat for 4-6 weeks, or until lesions resolve on ophthalmic exam.

regimenData.notes: Choice depends on Candida species and local susceptibility patterns. Voriconazole has better activity against non-albicans species.

criteriaBasedDuration.description: Treat for 4-6 weeks. May be stepped down to an oral azole.

procedureData.name: Intravitreal Injection
procedureData.indication: For patients with significant vitritis or sight-threatening lesions.
procedureData.notes: Amphotericin B (5-10 mcg) or Voriconazole (100 mcg) is injected directly into the vitreous. This provides high local drug concentrations.

procedureData.name: Pars Plana Vitrectomy
procedureData.indication: For severe, vision-threatening endophthalmitis, or cases that do not respond to medical therapy.
procedureData.notes: Surgical removal of the infected vitreous can reduce the fungal burden and clear inflammatory debris.

referenceData.text: See also: Endophthalmitis, Hematogenous or Endogenous
